sen.j: 奉納（ほうのう）とは、氏子・檀家が神仏を敬い、また鎮め愉しませる目的のため、人々にとって「価値のあるもの」を供物として神仏（お墓なども含む）に捧げる宗教的な行為のことをいう。
sen.e: Hono is a religious act performed by ujiko (shrine parishioner) and danka (supporter of a Buddhist temple) aimed at respecting or appeasing and pleasing Shinto and Buddhist deities with offering 'something of value' for people as altarage to such deities (including tombs).

Hono is a religious act performed by ujiko (shrine parishioners) and danka (supporters of a Buddhist temple) aimed at respecting or appeasing and pleasing Shinto and Buddhist deities in which people offer 'something of value' to such deities (including tombs).

sen.j: このため、奉納に用いられる対象は、必ずしも食物や酒、金銭や宝物などといった「物質」を納めることにかぎらない。
sen.e: Therefore, the offerings used in hono are not always 'materials' such as foods, liquor, money or treasures.

sen.j: 一般的にはむしろ神楽や謡曲、踊りや武芸、山車または神輿などの練りや巡行といった「行為」で捧げることも多い。
sen.e: Rather, in general, 'activities' such as kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines), Yokyoku (Noh song), dance, military art or parades and tours including dashi (float) or mikoshi (portable shrine carried in festivals) are offered in many cases.

sen.j: また古来においては、「生贄」や「人柱」などといった風習も残酷ではあるが、これもまた奉納のひとつの姿であるといえる。
sen.e: The custom of 'immolation' or 'human sacrifice' in ancient time, no matter how cruel it was, could also be regarded as one of the forms of hono.
The ancient customs of sacrifice and 'hitobashira' (the practice of burying people alive under pillars of buildings to ensure protection), although cruel, could also be regarded as a form of hono.

sen.j: 絵馬や算額などを奉納することもある。
sen.e: Tablets such as Ema (a votive horse tablet) or Sangaku (Japanese votive tablets featuring mathematical puzzles) are also occasionally offered as hono.
